title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Joe Biden said every US adult would be eligible for a coronavirus vaccination by May 1 and set the July 4 Independence Day holiday as a target for a return to some normality.

“I need you, I need every American to do their part,” Biden said on Thursday night in his first televised primetime address to the nation. “That will make this Independence Day something truly special, where we not only mark our independence as a nation but begin to mark our independence from this virus.”

He stuck to his estimate that the US would have enough vaccine supplies for all adults who wanted one by the end of May, but went a step further by directing all states, territories and tribes to make every person over 18 eligible for a jab by May 1.

Hours earlier the president signed into law his $1.9tn economic stimulus package in the Oval Office, marking one of the largest injections of government funds into the US economy in postwar history. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The US has crafted a plan with Japan, India and Australia to provide 1bn doses of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine to south-east Asian nations in a bid to counter Chinese influence in the Indo-Pacific region.

  • Bulgaria has become the latest country to halt distribution of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine over questions about whether it could lead to blood clots. Thailand postponed the public vaccination of its prime minister because of the growing concerns.

  • Hungary has agreed to buy 5m doses of the Chinese-made Sinopharm vaccine at a cost of about €30 per dose, making the jabs among the most expensive of any vaccine.

  • Sanofi, the French pharmaceuticals group, will start human trials for the second Covid-19 vaccine it has in development. The vaccine is based on mRNA technology and is being developed in partnership with US group Translate Bio.

  • Brazil's Congress has approved an $8bn emergency aid package to help deal with a second wave of the coronavirus pandemic that has triggered economic shutdowns across the country.

Here's how the world's illustrators responded to a year of Covid-19. Follow our live blog for the latest pandemic updates.

In the news

Cuomo faces impeachment probe New York legislators will open an impeachment investigation into state governor Andrew Cuomo after six women came forward to accuse him of sexual harassment or inappropriate behaviour. New York City mayor Bill de Blasio called the allegations against Cuomo “deeply troubling” and “disgusting”. (FT)

Jack Ma's private jet records show billionaire is down but not out The billionaire has made only one public appearance since upsetting the Chinese government last October. But the Financial Times has obtained the flight details of Ma's private jet, which suggest that while the 56-year-old is down, he is far from out. (FT)

ECB pledges to step up pace of stimulus The European Central Bank has pledged to accelerate bond buying over the next three months in response to rising borrowing costs and faltering economic recovery, prompting a eurozone bond rally.

  • Data from Japan's finance ministry showed investors purchased UK gilts at the quickest pace on record at the start of 2021 as fading Brexit risks removed a barrier to investment in British assets. (FT)

John Kerry warns EU against carbon border tax Joe Biden's climate envoy told the FT that Brussels' plans for a carbon border tax should be a “last resort”. Follow the latest climate news with the FT on Instagram: @ftclimate. (FT)

  • LG Energy Solution, the world's largest producer of electric vehicle batteries, is to invest $4.5bn in the US by 2025 to meet growing consumer demand for non-carbon emitting cars. (FT)

German towns braced for losses from Greensill Bank collapse German municipalities that held up to €500m with Greensill Bank, one of the few German lenders that accepted large deposits without charging negative interest rates, are preparing for the lender's collapse within days.

  • Senior Credit Suisse executives over-ruled risk managers to approve a $160m loan to Greensill Capital, which the finance group has “no conceivable way” to repay, according to people familiar with the matter. (FT)

Beeple collage sale smashes digital art record A collage by contemporary artist Beeple, composed as a single digital file, sold for $69.3m on Thursday, according to Christie's, in the latest and most extreme example of the rapidly appreciating market for digital artwork known as non-fungible tokens. (FT, Digiday)

Lula da Silva's return poses challenge to Bolsonaro in Brazil Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's dramatic return to frontline politics in Brazil this week sets the scene for a contest between opposite sides of the political spectrum in next year's presidential race. “[Jair] Bolsonaro knows that he now has a real opponent — a real gladiator in the political arena,” said one political observer. (FT)

The days ahead

‘Quad' meeting Joe Biden is set to hold the first-ever quadrilateral summit on Friday with the leaders of Japan, India and Australia as the countries step up co-operation to counter China's influence in the Indo-Pacific. (FT)

Economic data The US Bureau of Labor Statistics is to release the producer price indices for February. Statistics Canada is scheduled to release the monthly labour force survey for last month as well as trade figures. Mexico's national statistics agency releases industrial output data and Brazil's central bank is expected to publish economic activity data for January.

German state elections Germany's Greens are hoping that wins in regional elections in Rhineland-Palatinate and Baden-Württemberg this Sunday will bolster their claim to national power ahead of Bundestag polls in September. (FT)

What else we're reading

How do pandemics end? Since the start of the year, as more transmissible coronavirus variants have driven up infections, it has sometimes seemed that the pandemic will never end. History, however, teaches otherwise. Pandemics do finish — but their endings are rarely neat. (FT)

Emotions drive market swings Savvy players are undoubtedly feeding off retail players' “fast” thinking mistakes. But there is a wider lesson, writes Gillian Tett: if you want to understand share prices, look beyond valuation models or trading algorithms. (FT)

Like all firms, the British royal family must learn to listen on diversity No culture is so superior that it will survive without investigating new thinking, modernity and the beneficial elements of other cultures, writes Margaret Casely-Hayford.

  • Although, at 39, Meghan only scrapes into the millennial generation, her personality and outlook suggest that millennialism seeps through every pore. Not even the institution of the monarchy can muzzle them any more, writes Joe Ellison.

 Inside the university recruitment machine In the past two decades, the growth of the world's middle class has transformed education into a vast export industry. Young people from emerging economies are seeking life-changing opportunities in the UK, western Europe, Australia and North America — and are paying handsomely for them. (FT)

Technology has turned back the clock on productivity The modern worker is becoming a generalist, writes Tim Harford. Everyone does their own typing nowadays, and many people design their own presentations and manage their own diaries. Variety is pleasant — but a high-paid office job is no place for amateur hour. (FT)

In yesterday's edition of FirstFT we ran an item on the 10th anniversary of the Fukushima nuclear disaster. We understand the item failed to make sufficiently clear the cause of the vast majority of deaths was the tsunami, not the meltdown of the reactors.

Video of the day

Charts that count The reflation trade — which assumes a successful vaccine rollout, pent-up demand and fiscal stimulus will boost economic growth and prices — has dominated markets. The FT's Robert Armstrong explains why investors have embraced “reflation-mania” and what it means for different stocks. (FT)
